A meeting of the Baghdad Pact in Ankara, attended by Loy Henderson, a high-level of.cial of the U. S. State Department, agreed that the present regime in Syria had to go; otherwise the takeover by the Commu­nists would soon be complete.16 Turkish troops moved along the Syrian border in September, and the Turkish government hinted that it would not tolerate the Communists taking over power in Syria.
content_units.azure_translation: 在该地区反纳西尔主义势力的怂恿下，只能被描述为共产主义神经症，他们确信共产党即将接管叙利亚。美国国务院高级官员洛伊·亨德森（Loy Henderson）出席了在安卡拉举行的《巴格达条约》会议，一致认为叙利亚现政权必须下台;否则，共产党的接管很快就会完成。9月，16名土耳其军队沿叙利亚边境移动，土耳其政府暗示不会容忍共产党接管叙利亚政权。

content_units.text: Nasir had to take a stand in defense of his only remaining radical ally. He unleashed a barrage of propaganda against the United States and its stooges in the Arab world. For over two weeks, Egyptian radio maintained a relentless verbal onslaught against American imperialism and its alleged clients and supporters among the Arab governments. For good measure, Nasir dispatched a military contingent to Syria to aid in its defense. As a military deterrent, it was of little value, but in its symbolism, it had an elec­trifying impact on Arab public opinion. It portrayed Nasir as the unwavering defender of Arab nationalist principles, sharply con­trasting him with the other Arab leaders who, in their support of non-Arab Turkey against Syria, con.rmed in Arab perception their seemingly tepid commitment to Arab nationalism. By early Septem­ber, Nasirs political strategy was beginning to pay dividends, as the other leaders, now fully cognizant of the political cost of their stance, began feverishly to reassess their policies. One by one, Arab leaders, who had favored the American position, beat a hasty re­treat. The Jordanian foreign minister declared that it was never Jordans intent to interfere in Syrias domestic affairs; the Iraqi pre­mier, in a statement that must have hurt mightily, announced com­plete understanding with the Syrian President;17 and the Saudi king sent a message to the baf.ed and dejected American president urging caution and moderation. As the crisis subsided, it was obvi­ous to one and all that Egypt and Syria had won the day. In the ensuing euphoria, Anwar al-Sadat, the then-speaker of Egypts Par­liament, headed a parliamentary delegation on a visit to Damascus, at the conclusion of which the Syrian Parliament voted unani­mously for immediate union with Egypt.
content_units.azure_translation: 纳西尔不得不表明立场，捍卫他仅存的激进盟友。他对美国及其在阿拉伯世界的走狗进行了一连串的宣传。两个多星期以来，埃及广播电台对美帝国主义及其在阿拉伯政府中的所谓客户和支持者进行了无情的口头攻击。为了更好地衡量，纳西尔向叙利亚派遣了一支军事特遣队来协助其防御。作为一种军事威慑，它的价值不大，但就其象征意义而言，它对阿拉伯公众舆论产生了震撼人心的影响。它将纳西尔描绘成阿拉伯民族主义原则的坚定捍卫者，将他与其他阿拉伯领导人形成鲜明对比，后者在支持非阿拉伯土耳其对叙利亚的对立中，在阿拉伯人看来，他们对阿拉伯民族主义的承诺似乎不温不火。到 9 月初，纳西尔的政治策略开始得到回报，因为其他领导人现在完全认识到他们立场的政治代价，开始狂热地重新评估他们的政策。一个接一个地，支持美国立场的阿拉伯领导人匆忙撤退。约旦外交部长宣称，约旦从来无意干涉叙利亚内政;伊拉克总理在一份肯定会造成巨大伤害的声明中宣布与叙利亚总统完全谅解;17 沙特国王向 baf.ed 和沮丧的美国总统发出了一条信息，敦促谨慎和温和。随着危机的平息，埃及和叙利亚赢得了这一天。在随后的欣喜若狂中，时任埃及议会议长安瓦尔·萨达特率领议会代表团访问了大马士革，最后叙利亚议会一致投票支持立即与埃及合并。

content_units.text: Dwight D. Eisenhower, The White House Years, vol. 2: Waging Peace (New York: Doubleday, 1965), p. 197.
Patrick Seale, The Struggle for Syria: A Study of Post-War Arab Politics, 19451958 (New Haven, Connecticut: Yale University Press, 1986), p. 303.

If the Syrians thought that the champion of Arab nationalism would jump at their offer, they were soon to be disappointed. Nasir was skeptical. To a Syrian delegation, he expressed his concern over the proclivity of the Syrian armed forces for constant interfer­ence in their countrys domestic politics. He told the Bathist Salah Bitar: I have spent the last .ve years distancing the Egyptian army from politics.18 He also sent an emissary to Damascus to explain his seeming reluctance to join politically with Syria. The same ob­jections about the Syrian army were voiced, but further concerns were transmitted to the Syrians; concerns about the incompatibility of the two economies and the political imbalance between two dif­ferent party systems.19 It was obvious that during these highly emo­tional times, Nasir was trying to keep a level head about a project that could have momentous and unforeseen consequences. Realiz­ing the depth of Nasirs reservations about a possible unity with Syria, the Syrian leaders went all out to force his hand, not only because of their commitment to the Arab nationalist creed, but also because unity with Egypt had become the only means to preserve unity within Syria itself.
content_units.azure_translation: 如果叙利亚人认为阿拉伯民族主义的拥护者会接受他们的提议，他们很快就会失望。纳西尔对此表示怀疑。他向叙利亚代表团表示，他对叙利亚武装部队经常干涉其国内政治的倾向表示关切。他告诉巴斯蒂斯特萨拉赫·比塔尔：在过去的几年里，我一直在与埃及军队保持距离，使其与政治保持距离。18 他还派了一位使者到大马士革，解释他似乎不愿在政治上与叙利亚合作。对叙利亚军队也提出了同样的反对意见，但进一步的担忧也传达给了叙利亚人;对两个经济的不相容以及两个不同政党制度之间的政治失衡的担忧。19 很明显，在这些高度情绪化的时期，纳西尔试图对一个可能产生重大和不可预见后果的项目保持冷静。叙利亚领导人意识到纳西尔对与叙利亚可能统一持保留态度，因此全力以赴迫使他出手，这不仅是因为他们对阿拉伯民族主义信条的承诺，还因为与埃及的统一已成为维持叙利亚内部统一的唯一手段。

content_units.text: The end of 1957 saw a near paralysis of political life in Syria. The crisis of late summer had all but abated, but had left in its wake three forces competing against one another: the conservative feudalist and .nancial classes, the Arab nationalists, Bathists or Nasirists, and the Communists and their sympathizers. These divi­sions probably would not have been so critical had they not been mirrored within the ranks of the military, where there was such diffusion of power that no one group could impose its will on the others and restore order.
content_units.azure_translation: 1957年底，叙利亚的政治生活几乎瘫痪。夏末的危机几乎平息了，但随之而来的是三股相互竞争的力量：保守的封建主义阶级和金融阶级、阿拉伯民族主义者、巴斯主义者或纳西尔主义者，以及共产党人及其同情者。如果这些部门没有反映在军队队伍中，它们可能不会如此关键，因为军队的权力如此分散，以至于没有一个团体可以将其意志强加于其他团体并恢复秩序。

content_units.text: Ahmad Hamroush, Qissat Thawrat 23 Yuliyu, al-Jusial-Rabi: Abd al-Nasir wa al­Arab (The story of the 23 July revolution, volume 4: Abd al-Nasir and the Arabs) (Cairo: Dar al-Mawqif al-Arabi, 1983), p. 42.
Nasr, Abd al-Nasir wa Tajribat al-Wuhda (Abd al-Nasir and the experiment of unity), p. 118.

From all these competing groups, the Bath Party stood out as the one organized institution that had consistently and genuinely agitated for the political unity of the Arab nation. Cognizant of the paralysis that had mired Syrias political circles, which con­trasted with the mounting public clamor for some kind of action in the direction of union with Nasirs Egypt, the Bath drafted in December a project for federal union. The drafting of the document came as no surprise to Bathist supporters or to other Arab nation­alists. What was surprising was the tone of the document and the kind of union proposed. A federal union might have been a con­siderable step forward at a time when the Arab world was wracked with political divisions and acrimonious recriminations. But to fer­vent Bathists and other Arab nationalists, anything but an organic unity of what they considered to be the arti.cially separated re­gions of the eternal and indivisible Arab nation was an anemic alternative indeed. The Bathist leaders, however, had their reasons, which were grounded less in ideological yearnings and more in po­litical realities. As Michel A.aq explained:
content_units.azure_translation: 在所有这些相互竞争的团体中，巴斯党脱颖而出，成为一个始终如一地真诚地鼓动阿拉伯民族政治统一的有组织的机构。巴斯意识到叙利亚政界陷入瘫痪，这与公众要求采取某种行动朝着与埃及纳西尔联合方向采取某种行动的呼声形成鲜明对比，巴斯于 12 月起草了一项联邦联盟项目。该文件的起草对于巴斯派的支持者或其他阿拉伯民族主义者来说并不奇怪。令人惊讶的是该文件的语气和提议的联盟类型。在阿拉伯世界饱受政治分歧和尖锐指责蹂躏的时候，联邦联盟可能是向前迈出的一大步。但对于狂热的巴斯主义者和其他阿拉伯民族主义者来说，除了他们认为是永恒和不可分割的阿拉伯民族的人工分离地区的有机统一之外，任何东西都确实是一个乏味的替代方案。然而，巴斯派领导人有他们的理由，这些理由不是基于意识形态的渴望，而是更多地基于政治现实。正如米歇尔·A.aq 所解释的那样：

content_units.text: We wanted two things which may seem contradictory. On the one hand, we wanted a federal state strong enough and centralized enough to stand .rm against the maneuvers of opponents at home and foreign governments abroad. The federal institutions would have to be more than a facade.... But our wish for a strong govern­ment was tempered by a second consideration. We wanted a federa­tion to make allowances for the different political histories of the two countries. We believed that a sensitivity to local traditions was not only in the interests of the proposed union itself, but was also essential to make it attractive to other Arab countries. In our project we provided, for instance, for effective local parliaments and gov­ernments in each province.20
content_units.azure_translation: 我们想要两件看似矛盾的事情。一方面，我们想要一个足够强大、足够集中的联邦国家，能够.rm对抗国内反对者和国外外国政府的诡计。联邦机构必须不仅仅是一个门面......但我们对一个强大政府的愿望被第二个考虑因素所削弱。我们希望建立一个联邦来考虑两国不同的政治历史。我们认为，对当地传统的敏感不仅符合拟议联盟本身的利益，而且对于使其对其他阿拉伯国家具有吸引力也至关重要。例如，在我们的项目中，我们为每个省份提供了有效的地方议会和政府。

content_units.text: Seale, The Struggle for Syria, p. 318.

In retrospect, this might have been a better and more workable prototype for union than the one eventually agreed on, but no sooner had it been drafted, than it had been overtaken by events. The Communists and their sympathizers were loathe to allow the Bathists to take the initiative, even though they favored an even looser federation in which their party would continue to operate legally. Their tactic was simple: up the ante, and demand total or­ganic unity. In the one-upmanship game that characterized fac­tionalized Syrian politics at the end of 1957, the Communists would outbid the Bath, yet remain secure in the knowledge that Nasir, who had shown himself to be against even a loose federa­tion, would reject the proposal out of hand. But in trying to outma­neuver the Bath, the Communists ended up outmaneuvering them­selves, for they were unprepared for the rapid unfolding of events spearheaded by a public driven to frenzy by all the talk and prom­ises of union with Egypt. A.f al-Bizri, Syrias chief of staff and a Communist sympathizer, explains well the developing situation, in which the political parties outbidding of each other interacted with the volatile sentiments of the Syrian public, with the result of inducing the Syrian of.cers to travel to Cairo and literally hand over their country to Nasir. Bizri maintains that none of the Syrian politicians really wanted unity. In fact,
content_units.azure_translation: 回想起来，这可能比最终商定的工会原型更好、更可行，但它刚起草，就被事件所取代。共产党人及其同情者不愿让巴斯派采取主动，尽管他们赞成建立一个更宽松的联邦，让他们的政党继续合法运作。他们的策略很简单：提高赌注，要求完全有机的团结。在 1957 年底叙利亚派系化政治特征的单挑游戏中，共产党人出价高于巴斯，但仍然很安全，因为纳西尔已经表明自己反对即使是松散的联邦也会立即拒绝这一提议。但是，在试图战胜巴斯的过程中，共产党最终战胜了自己，因为他们没有为公众带头的事件迅速发展做好准备，这些事件被所有关于与埃及联合的言论和承诺所驱使而疯狂。叙利亚参谋长、共产主义同情者 A.f al-Bizri 很好地解释了事态发展，在这种局势中，相互出价的政党与叙利亚公众的动荡情绪互动，其结果是诱使叙利亚人前往开罗，将他们的国家真正交给纳西尔。比兹里坚持认为，没有一个叙利亚政客真正想要团结。事实上

content_units.text: . . . no one wanted unity. Even Abd al-Nasser didnt want it.... So
content_units.azure_translation: . . .没有人想要团结。就连阿卜杜勒·纳赛尔也不想要它......所以

content_units.text: I . . . waited for the appropriate moment and said: now we will offer unity to Abd al-Nasser. Since theyre all saying, unity, unity, unity. Nobody would dare to say no, we dont want it. The masses would rise against them. I mean we followed the masses. The crowds were drunk.... Who at that hour could dare say we do not want unity? The people would tear their heads off.21
content_units.azure_translation: 我。。。等待适当的时机并说：现在我们将向阿卜杜勒·纳赛尔提供团结。既然他们都在说，团结，团结，团结。没有人敢说不，我们不想要它。群众会起来反对他们。我的意思是我们追随群众。人群喝醉了......在那个时候，谁敢说我们不想要团结呢？人们会把他们的头撕下来21。

content_units.text: Bizri and the military had decided to take matters into their own hands. On January 11, 1958, .fteen of.cers, led by Bizri, informed the Egyptian military attache´ in Damascus of their intention to go to Cairo, and then immediately boarded a military plane and headed to Egypt. No Syrian politician was told of the trip until the of.cers had arrived in Cairo. Informed about the Syrian initiative, Egypts ambassador to Syria, Mahmoud Riad, drove to the Presi­dential Palace to discuss the rapidly developing situation with Syrias president, Shukri al-Quwatly. Understandably, Quwatly was incensed, accusing Riad of complicity, and repeatedly charac­terizing the action by Bizri and the other of.cers as a military coup. He told Riad pointedly that only the Syrian government had the authority to make a decision on unity.22 Syrias politicians could hardly be expected to get excited about a unity that would be bound not only to make Syria a satellite of Egypt, but also to push Syrias political leaders out onto the margins of political life in their own country.
content_units.azure_translation: 比兹里和军方决定自己动手。1958 年 1 月 11 日，在比兹里的带领下，15 名士兵通知了埃及驻大马士革武官他们打算前往开罗，然后立即登上军机前往埃及。在他们抵达开罗之前，没有叙利亚政客被告知这次旅行。埃及驻叙利亚大使马哈茂德·里亚德（Mahmoud Riad）获悉叙利亚倡议后，驱车前往总统府，与叙利亚总统舒克里·库瓦特利（Shukri al-Quwatly）讨论迅速发展的局势。可以理解的是，库瓦特利被激怒了，指责里亚德同谋，并一再将比兹里和其他人的行动定性为军事政变。他尖锐地告诉里亚德，只有叙利亚政府才有权就统一做出决定。22 很难指望叙利亚政客们会对一个团结感到兴奋，因为这种统一不仅会使叙利亚成为埃及的卫星国，而且还会将叙利亚政治领导人推到他们自己国家政治生活的边缘。

content_units.text: Quoted in Malik Mufti, Sovereign Creations: Pan Arabism and Political Order in Syria and Iraq (Ithaca, New York: Cornell University Press, 1996), p. 91.

Interesting enough, the Egyptian leaders were just as wary about the proposed unity as their Syrian counterparts.The entire up­per echelon of Egypts policy-making elite advised Nasir against what appeared to be a headlong dive into unitary schemes. Intelli­gence of.cers offered a gloomy prognosis of Syrias stability, citing the inordinate political power of the military of.cers and their reg­ular interventions in the political process. Some of Nasirs most senior colleagues emphasized the incompatibility of the two politi­cal systems. Egypt had banned political parties, creating the unitary and closely controlled National Union; Syria had a multiparty sys­tem, which spanned the ideological spectrum from the far left to the far right. The Bath and the Communist parties in Syria were active and well organized, and it was an open question as to whether they would accept a life of political anonymity. If any­thing, the chances were that very quickly they would become a source of intrigue and conspiracy.
content_units.azure_translation: 有趣的是，埃及领导人和叙利亚领导人一样对拟议的统一持谨慎态度。埃及决策精英的整个上层都建议纳西尔不要一头扎进单一计划。Intelligence of.cers 对叙利亚的稳定做出了悲观的预测，理由是 Mils of.cers 军队的过度政治权力及其对政治进程的定期干预。纳西尔的一些最资深同事强调了两种政治制度的不相容。埃及取缔了政党，建立了统一且严格控制的民族联盟;叙利亚实行多党制，跨越了从极左翼到极右翼的意识形态光谱。巴斯和叙利亚的共产党活跃且组织良好，他们是否会接受政治隐姓埋名的生活是一个悬而未决的问题。如果有的话，他们很可能很快就会成为阴谋和阴谋的来源。

content_units.text: Then there was the absence of a common geographic border. Not only that but in between the two segments of the proposed unitary state lay none other than the state of Israel. Overall, the political and geostrategic obstacles seemed daunting.23 The eco­nomic conditions did not offer great hopes either. In Egypt, the currency was the pound, and the economy was shifting purpose­fully toward central planning, whereas in Syria, the currency was the lira, with an economy based primarily on freewheeling business practices and transactions.24 The Egyptians were thus worried that Syrias smaller economy would become a burden on Egypts trea­sury. And then there were those Egyptian leaders with Islamist tendencies, prime among them Kemal al-Din Husayn, who seemed to .nd the existence of Christians in leadership roles in Syria some­what unpalatable. When asked his opinion about unity with Syria by Nasir, Husayn replied: I do not trust them.... The Bathist leaders at present are agents. And Michel A.aq and Antun Saada are the biggest agents. And they are working against Islam.25 Per­haps the most telling advice came from Fathi Radwan, another member of Nasirs inner circle. Radwan cautioned his president: Tomorrow, you are going to become the President of the Syrian state, and you have not even put your foot in it, nor do you know much about it, nor have you given this step much thought.26 Nasir readily agreed, for he related to Radwan a conversation he had with Salah Bitar, the Bathist leader and Syrias foreign minister, who had joined the negotiations in Cairo on January 16 and who was trying to encourage Nasir to accept the Syrian proposals. Bitar told me, Nasir said, when a person prepares to dive into a swimming pool, he has an initial fear of the water, but this fear disappears once he has jumped into the water. So I told him, Brother Salah, what scares me is that I may be jumping into an empty pool.27 Given all these apprehensions and concerns, it is not clear whether the Syrian of.cers, who took off for Cairo on January 11, really understood what a tough sell they had on their hands.
content_units.azure_translation: 然后是没有共同的地理边界。不仅如此，在拟议的单一国家的两个部分之间，正是以色列国。总体而言，政治和地缘战略障碍似乎令人生畏。23 经济状况也没有带来很大的希望。在埃及，货币是英镑，经济有目的地转向中央计划，而在叙利亚，货币是里拉，经济主要基于随心所欲的商业行为和交易。24 因此，埃及人担心叙利亚较小的经济体会成为埃及国库的负担。还有那些具有伊斯兰主义倾向的埃及领导人，其中最主要的是凯末尔·丁·侯赛因（Kemal al-Din Husayn），他似乎对基督徒在叙利亚担任领导职务感到有些令人不快。当纳西尔问及他对与叙利亚的统一的看法时，侯赛因回答说：我不信任他们......目前的巴斯派领导人是代理人。米歇尔·A.aq 和安通·萨达是最大的经纪人。他们正在反对伊斯兰教。25 也许最有说服力的建议来自纳西尔核心圈子的另一位成员法蒂·拉德万。拉德万告诫他的总统：明天，你将成为叙利亚国家的总统，你甚至没有踏入其中，你对它了解不多，也没有考虑过这一步。26 纳西尔欣然同意了，因为他向拉德万讲述了他与巴斯派领导人兼叙利亚外交部长萨拉赫·比塔尔的谈话，萨拉赫·比塔尔于 1 月 16 日参加了开罗的谈判，并试图鼓励纳西尔接受叙利亚的提议。纳西尔说，比塔尔告诉我，当一个人准备跳入游泳池时，他最初会对水产生恐惧，但一旦他跳入水中，这种恐惧就会消失。所以我告诉他，萨拉赫兄弟，让我害怕的是，我可能会跳进一个空荡荡的游泳池。27 鉴于所有这些担忧和担忧，尚不清楚 1 月 11 日起飞前往开罗的叙利亚人是否真的了解他们手上的艰难销售。

content_units.text: Ibid., p. 92.
See Hamroush, Qissat Thawrat 23 Yuliyu (The story of the 23 July revolution), pp. 4345; Nasr, Abd al-Nasir wa Tajribat al-Wuhda (Abd al-Nasir and the experiment of unity), pp. 124125.
Sayed Marei, Awraq Siyasiya (Political papers) (Cairo: Al-Maktab al-Misri al-Hadith, 1978), pp. 392393. Marei was the UARs Central Minister for Agriculture.

Samir Gawhar, al-Samitun Yatakalamun: Abd al-Nasir wa Madhbahat al-Ikhwan (The silent speak: Abd al-Nasir and the massacre of the [Muslim] brothers) (Cairo: al-Mak­tab al-Misri al-Hadith, 1975), p. 112. The interesting observation about this quote is that Michel A.aq, the committed believer in Arab unity, had nothing in common with the viru­lently Syrian nationalist Antun Saada, who in any case had been executed in 1949! It is only because the two were Christians, supposedly working against Islam, that Husayn would lump them together.
Fathi Radwan, 72 Shahran maa Abd al-Nasir (72 months with Abd al-Nasir) (Cairo: Dar al-Huriya, 1986), p. 104.

The of.cers who .ew to Cairo represented a true microcosm of the militarys factionalized state. There were Bathists, Nasirists, Communist sympathizers, and representatives of the feudal / mer­chant oligarchy. As Nasir would later comment, the Syrian army seemed to be divided into clans and parties.28 But divided ideo­logically as they were, they now put up a united front in waving all the Egyptian objections aside, telling Nasir categorically that without unity, Syria would implode. The Arab nationalists among them also hinted that Syria was on the verge of falling into the hands of the Communists. With that, the Syrians left Nasir with no option. He was effectively cornered. He was after all the hero of Arab nationalism, the man who, to the applause, adulation, and eternal gratitude of every Arab nationalist, came to Syrias aid only a few months earlier when it faced imperialist threats from Tur­key, Iraq and the United States. How could he now abandon it to internal disintegration and political ruin? Could the prophet of Arab nationalism turn a deaf ear to these urgent appeals made in the very name of Arab nationalism? Nasir, his options severely lim­ited by the Arab nationalist discourse, which had shaped his politi­cal relations with the rest of the Arab world since 1955, had little choice but to accept, but against his better judgment. He was later to expound on the dialogue that shaped the negotiations:
content_units.azure_translation: 前往开罗的 of.cers 代表了军方派系化国家的真实缩影。有巴西斯特、纳西尔主义者、共产主义同情者和封建/商人寡头政治的代表。正如纳西尔后来评论的那样，叙利亚军队似乎分裂成了部族和党派。28 但是，尽管他们在意识形态上存在分歧，但现在他们建立了统一战线，将埃及的所有反对意见抛在一边，明确地告诉纳西尔，如果没有团结，叙利亚就会崩溃。其中的阿拉伯民族主义者也暗示叙利亚即将落入共产党手中。这样一来，叙利亚人就让纳西尔别无选择。他实际上被逼入绝境。毕竟，他是阿拉伯民族主义的英雄，在每个阿拉伯民族主义者的掌声、奉承和永恒的感激之情中，几个月前，当叙利亚面临来自土耳其、伊拉克和美国的帝国主义威胁时，他才向叙利亚提供援助。他现在怎么能放弃它，让内部解体和政治毁灭呢？阿拉伯民族主义的先知能对这些以阿拉伯民族主义的名义提出的紧急呼吁置若罔闻吗？纳西尔的选择受到阿拉伯民族主义话语的严重限制，自 1955 年以来，阿拉伯民族主义话语塑造了他与阿拉伯世界其他地区的政治关系，他别无选择，只能接受，但违背了他更好的判断。他后来阐述了影响谈判的对话：

content_units.text: I told them: let us pave the way for unity because unity needs prepa­ration, because unity is tantamount to troubles and problems, and because it is an inter-mixture. I said this but they told me: where are the aims that you have advocated? Where are the aims that you have proclaimed? Will you go back on those aims? . . . will you leave Syria to be torn by strife? Will you let Syria be lost? I said: Never. To me . . . it is a sector of the Arab homeland in which I have laid my faith. I said: I agree to unity.29
content_units.azure_translation: 我告诉他们：让我们为团结铺平道路，因为团结需要准备，因为团结无异于麻烦和问题，因为它是一种混合体。我这么说，但他们告诉我：你倡导的目标在哪里？你宣布的目标在哪里？你会回到这些目标上吗？. . .你会离开叙利亚，让冲突撕裂吗？你会让叙利亚迷失吗？我说：从来没有。对我来说。。。这是我所信奉的阿拉伯家园的一个地区。我说：我同意合一29。

content_units.text: Ibid. 28 Stephens, Nasser: A Political Biography, p. 274.

Having received Nasirs agreement, the Syrian of.cers .ew back to Damascus, and in a move which should have forewarned Nasir, informed the Syrian cabinet of what had transpired in Cairo, and commanded them to get ready to go to the Egyptian capital. On January 31, the of.cers, under the direction of A.f al-Bizri, assem­bled the cabinet and put them on a plane headed for Cairo. Khalid al-Azm describes bitterly the brazen manner by which the army of.cers imposed their will on the politicians, some of whom, such as Azm, had reservations about Nasirs style of personalized rule. The of.cers herded us like sheep, Azm relates, and put us on a plane which took all of usthe President, Ministers and senior army of.cersto Cairo, where meetings were held in al-Qubba Palace which ended with signing the unity agreement . . . then they .ew us back the following day into a military air.eld, where they gave us a lunch of rice, meat and a piece of bread that was served on a metal plate.30 This must have been particularly galling to a wealthy aristocrat such as Azm, even with his announced leftist leanings. Patrick Seale con.rms the militarys high-handedness. He writes that Bizri literally ordered the members of the Cabinet into the departing plane, and to the more recalcitrant of the group, he was supposed to have said: there are two roads open to you: one leads to Mezza (a notorious prison); the other to Cairo.31 They promptly decided to take the high road to Cairo. The following day, February 1, 1958, the amalgamation of Egypt and Syria into the United Arab Republic (UAR) was proclaimed.
content_units.azure_translation: 在得到纳西尔的同意后，叙利亚人返回大马士革，并采取了本应预先警告纳西尔的举动，将开罗发生的事情通知了叙利亚内阁，并命令他们准备前往埃及首都。1 月 31 日，在 A.f al-Bizri 的指导下，of.cers 组装了内阁，并将它们放在一架飞往开罗的飞机上。哈立德·阿兹姆 （Khalid al-Azm） 痛苦地描述了塞尔军队将他们的意志强加给政客的厚颜无耻的方式，其中一些人，如阿兹姆，对纳西尔式的个人统治持保留态度。阿兹姆说，奥塞尔人像羊一样驱赶我们，把我们送上一架飞机，载着我们所有人总统、部长和高级军队前往开罗，在库巴宫举行会议，最后签署了团结协议......然后第二天，他们把我们带回了军用空军，在那里他们给了我们一顿午餐，里面有米饭、肉和一块面包，放在金属盘子上。30 对于像阿兹姆这样的富有贵族来说，这一定特别令人恼火，即使他宣布了左翼倾向。帕特里克·西尔 （Patrick Seale） 认为军方的专横。他写道，比兹里确实命令内阁成员进入离开的时空，对于这群人中比较顽固的人，他应该说：有两条路向你敞开：一条通往梅扎（臭名昭著的监狱）;另一艘前往开罗。31 他们立即决定走大路前往开罗。第二天，即 1958 年 2 月 1 日，埃及和叙利亚宣布并入阿拉伯联合共和国 （UAR）。

content_units.text: While Nasir was pushed into the union against his better judg­ment, he nevertheless made sure that a united state would be estab­lished only in accordance with his terms, not those of the Syrians.
content_units.azure_translation: 虽然纳西尔违背了他更好的判断力被推入联邦，但他仍然确保一个统一的国家只能根据他的条件而不是叙利亚人的条件建立。

content_units.text: SWB, September 29, 1961, p. 9. 30 Al-Azm, Mudhakarat Khalid al-Azm (The memoirs of Khalid al-Azm), pp. 197198. 31 Seale, The Struggle for Syria, p. 323.

He insisted on a comprehensive merger in which the Syrian politi­cal system would be fused into that of Egypt, adopting the latters political and social institutions. This meant that all political parties had to be dissolved, the Syrian army had to withdraw from politics, the two economies had to be blended, and state control and agricul­tural reform had to be extended to Syria.
content_units.azure_translation: 他坚持进行全面合并，将叙利亚的政治制度与埃及的政治制度融合在一起，采用埃及的政治和社会制度。这意味着必须解散所有政党，叙利亚军队必须退出政坛，两种经济必须融合，国家控制和农业改革必须扩展到叙利亚。

content_units.text: The Syrian politicians naturally were hardly thrilled by Nasirs conditions. The conservatives and Communists knew that theirs was the bleakest future; their equivalents in Egypt had fared not well at all in the kind of society Nasir was building in Egypt. Even the Bathists were anything but ecstatic about the dissolution of their party, and they made desperate efforts to backtrack into their original federal proposal.32 Over secret deliberations, the various factions within the Syrian cabinet got together and came up with a counterproposal which emphasized the federal nature of the union, thus giving each country greater autonomy than Nasir had proposed. But the Syrians now were clutching at straws, and they knew it. At this late stage of the process, there was no turning back, unless, to quote Bizris chilling words again, they wished to have their heads torn off by the people. The entire Arab world fol­lowed the progress of the talks fervently, and with mounting frenzy, demanding immediate unity, and expecting it to be on Nasirs terms. So when Nasir .atly rejected the Syrian revised draft, insisting that only his conception of the union was on the table, the Syrian parties and politicians had no choice but to sign on the dotted line.
content_units.azure_translation: 叙利亚政客们自然对纳西尔的条件并不感到兴奋。保守派和共产党人知道他们的未来是最黯淡的;他们在埃及的同类国家在纳西尔在埃及建立的那种社会中表现得一点也不好。就连巴斯派也对他们政党的解散感到欣喜若狂，他们拼命努力撤回他们最初的联邦提案。32 经过秘密审议，叙利亚内阁内的各个派别聚集在一起，提出了一个反提案，强调联盟的联邦性质，从而赋予每个国家比纳西尔提议更大的自治权。但叙利亚人现在紧抓着救命稻草，他们知道这一点。在这个过程的后期阶段，没有回头路，除非再次引用比兹里斯令人不寒而栗的话，他们希望被人们撕下他们的头。整个阿拉伯世界都热切地关注着谈判的进展，而且越来越疯狂，要求立即团结，并期望谈判按照纳西尔的条件进行。因此，当纳西尔拒绝叙利亚修订草案，坚持认为只有他的联盟概念摆在桌面上时，叙利亚政党和政客别无选择，只能在虚线上签字。

content_units.text: Arabs everywhere heard the news of the merger with stunned amazement, which quickly turned into uncontrolled euphoria. Spontaneous celebrations occurred in many parts of the Arab world, and people congratulated one another in their homes, on the streets, and in their of.ces. One in.uential Arab journalist de­scribed the announcement of the UAR as the greatest hour in the history of the Arabs since the . . . victories of Salah al-Din [al-Ay­yubi].33 The outpouring of public support for the UAR attained its greatest expression in Syria. Akram al-Hourani, a Bathist leader and the president of Syrias Chamber of Deputies (Parliament) de­scribes vividly the elation that engulfed Damascus in the days that followed the proclamation of the UAR.34 He writes that Damascus was immediately invaded by hordes of people from Aleppo, Hama, Homs, Latikiya, and other Syrian districts. Along with their Dama­scene compatriots, they .lled every street and every square of their capital. Unable to contain their joy, they sang, listened to im­promptu patriotic orations, danced the dabka (Syrian folk dance), and made up instant poetic slogans that were rhythmically sung and repeated by all. The following are a few of these poetic slogans. They are interesting in the sense that they re.ected the political proclivities of the Syrian public in those heady days:
content_units.azure_translation: 各地的阿拉伯人听到合并的消息，都惊愕不已，很快就变成了不受控制的欣喜若狂。阿拉伯世界的许多地方都举行了自发的庆祝活动，人们在家中、街头和家里互相祝贺。一位有影响力的阿拉伯记者将阿拉伯联合共和国的宣布描述为阿拉伯人历史上自......萨拉赫丁 [al-Ayyubi] 的胜利。33 公众对 UAR 的大量支持在叙利亚得到了最大的体现。巴斯派领袖、叙利亚众议院（议会）主席阿克拉姆·胡拉尼 （Akram al-Hourani） 生动地描述了 UAR 宣布后的几天里席卷大马士革的兴高采烈。34 他写道，大马士革立即遭到来自阿勒颇、哈马、霍姆斯、拉蒂基亚和其他叙利亚地区的成群结队的入侵。他们与大马士革同胞一起，占领了首都的每条街道和每个广场。他们无法抑制自己的喜悦，唱歌，听即兴的爱国演讲，跳达布卡（叙利亚民间舞蹈），并立即编造诗意的口号，有节奏地唱着，所有人都重复着。以下是其中的一些诗意口号。它们很有趣，因为它们重新描述了叙利亚公众在那些令人兴奋的日子里的政治倾向：

content_units.text: Mufti, Sovereign Creations, pp. 9394. 33 Taha, Qissat al-Wuhda wa al-In.sal (The story of the unity and separation), p. 101.
wahdat Misr wa Suriya  the unity of Egypt and Syria
content_units.azure_translation: wahdat Misr wa Suriya，埃及和叙利亚的统一

content_units.text: jisr al-wuhda al-Arabiya  is the bridge of Arab unity
content_units.azure_translation: jisr al-wuhda al-Arabiya 是阿拉伯团结的桥梁

content_units.text: shawka bi ayn al-rajiya  and a thorn in the eye of reaction
content_units.azure_translation: Shawka Bi Ayn al-Rajiya 和反应的眼中钉

content_units.text: dhid al-istimar wahlaful  against imperialism and its
content_units.azure_translation: 反对帝国主义及其帝国主义的 Dhid al-istimar wahlaful

content_units.text: al-askariya  military alliances
content_units.azure_translation: 阿斯卡里亚军事联盟

content_units.text: To emphasize the secular nature of Arab nationalism, and its egali­tarian promise of social justice, the frolicking multitude would chant:
content_units.azure_translation: 为了强调阿拉伯民族主义的世俗性质及其对社会正义的平等承诺，嬉戏的群众会高呼：

content_units.text: badna wuhda Arabiya we seek Arab unity Islam wa Nisraniya of Islam and Christianity wa adala ijtimaiya and social justice
content_units.azure_translation: 巴德纳·乌达·阿拉比亚 我们寻求阿拉伯团结伊斯兰教和基督教的尼斯拉尼亚和基督教和社会正义

content_units.text: Of course, the unity of Egypt and Syria brought to mind other pressing Arab concerns. Foremost among these was the four-year old Algerian revolution against French colonialism, which claimed the following chant:
content_units.azure_translation: 当然，埃及和叙利亚的统一让人想起了其他紧迫的阿拉伯问题。其中最重要的是长达四年的阿尔及利亚反对法国殖民主义的革命，该革命声称有以下口号：

content_units.text: huriya lil Jazair freedom to Algeria lil watan al-Arabi al-to the revolutionary Arab
content_units.azure_translation: huriya lil Jazair 自由到阿尔及利亚 lil watan al-Arabi al-to 革命的阿拉伯人

content_units.text: Thair homeland
content_units.azure_translation: 泰尔故乡

content_units.text: Al-Quds al-Arabi (London), May 2930, 1999. This paper serialized Houranis mem­oirs. This particular issue contained the 85th installment.
And how could this repertoire be complete without reference to the one man who by then had constituted in the minds of this na­tionalist generation the most detested enemy of Arab nationalism:
content_units.azure_translation: 如果不提到那个在民族主义一代人心目中构成阿拉伯民族主义最令人厌恶的敌人的人，这些曲目怎么可能完整呢？

content_units.text: khain ya Nuri al-Said traitor, O Nuri al-Said shabina mithlal hadid our people are (made) of steel
content_units.azure_translation: Khain ya Nuri al-Said 叛徒，O Nuri al-Said shabina mithlal hadid 我们的人民是由钢铁（制成）的

content_units.text: These and other largely spontaneous chants and slogans were at the heart of the festivities that lasted several days, invariably con­tinuing through the night. No wonder then that the referendum in the two countries registered almost unanimous approval of the new united state, 99.25 in Syria and 99.8in Egypt. Some have disputed these .gures. Khalid al-Azm, a bitter foe of the union, alleges that ballot boxes were illegally stuffed with ballots, to the extent that in some districts, the ballots exceeded the number of registered vot­ers.35 Be that as it may, and indeed it was in the interest of the new political leadership to portray the union as universally supported, the UAR, without a shadow of doubt, commanded the overwhelm­ing and ecstatic support of the vast majority of Syrians. However, in the case of Egypt, where Arab national awareness lagged consid­erably behind that of Syria, the .gure could indeed have been in­.ated by the centralizing regime.
content_units.azure_translation: 这些和其他基本上自发的口号和口号是持续数天的庆祝活动的核心，总是持续到晚上。难怪两国的公投几乎一致支持新美国，叙利亚以 99.25 票，埃及以 99.8 票。有些人对这些 .gures 提出异议。工会的死敌哈立德·阿兹姆声称，投票箱被非法塞满选票，以至于在一些地区，选票超过了登记选民的人数。35 尽管如此，而且确实符合新政治领导层的利益，将工会描绘成得到普遍支持， 毫无疑问，UAR 获得了绝大多数叙利亚人的压倒性和欣喜若狂的支持。然而，就埃及而言，阿拉伯的民族意识远远落后于叙利亚，.gure 确实可能被中央集权政权所取代。

content_units.text: Having been told of the public delirium in Syria, Nasir arrived unannounced in Damascus on the morning of February 24, and headed straight to the house of President Shukri al-Quwatly. As news of Nasirs arrival spread, vast numbers of people of all ages left their workplaces and homes, some still in their nightdresses, and made their way to Quwatlys house. It was an awesome sight, recalls Hourani, this sea of colliding humanity which gath­ered with astonishing speed.36 When the two presidents and the other dignitaries decided to move from Quwatlys residence to the of.cial guesthouse, which was a mere 150 yards away, they were mobbed by the people whose numbers had swelled from the thou­ sands to the hundreds of thousands.37 Even though the of.cial car was ringed by soldiers, the crush was such that Quwatly nearly fainted. And a distance that could be walked in less than .ve min­utes, took the of.cial open-air car over two hours to cover.38 Nasir and the Egyptian entourage stayed in the presidential guesthouse for a week, during which hundreds of speeches were made to the adoring multitude camped outside. Anwar al-Sadat was a member of Nasirs entourage. He wrote in his autobiography:
content_units.azure_translation: 纳西尔被告知叙利亚的公众精神错乱后，于 2 月 24 日上午未经通知抵达大马士革，直奔总统舒克里·库瓦特利 （Shukri al-Quwatly） 的家。随着纳西尔到来的消息传开，大量各个年龄段的人离开了他们的工作场所和家，有些人还穿着睡裙，前往库瓦特利斯的家。胡拉尼回忆说，这是一个令人敬畏的景象，这片碰撞的人类海洋以惊人的速度聚集在一起。36 当两位总统和其他政要决定从库瓦特利的住所搬到距离酒店仅 150 码的宾馆时，他们遭到了人群的围攻，这些人数从沙漠中膨胀到数十万人。37 尽管警察的汽车被士兵包围，但压迫程度如此之大，以至于库瓦特利差点晕倒。而步行不到五分钟的距离，却需要两个多小时才能走完。38 纳西尔和埃及随行人员在总统宾馆住了一个星期，在此期间，向外面扎营的崇拜群众发表了数百场演讲。安瓦尔·萨达特是纳西尔随行人员的成员。他在自传中写道：

content_units.text: Al-Azm, Mudhakarat Khalid al-Azm (The memoirs of Khalid al-Azm), pp. 163165. 36 Al-Quds al-Arabi (London), May 2930, 1999.

I really feel incapable of describing that week. It was like a constant deliriuma stream of [speeches] that .owed day and night.... The crowds could not get enough and seemed to grow increasingly fren­zied. All that was said was hailed, applauded, celebrated. People chanted and screamed and called for more. For a whole week the crowds besieged the Guesthouse. They camped outside in the wide square, eating, drinking, and sleeping in the open air.39
content_units.azure_translation: 我真的觉得无法描述那一周。这就像一个持续不断的谵妄，一连串的[演讲]日夜欠着......人群无法满足，似乎变得越来越疯狂。所说的一切都受到了欢呼、掌声和庆祝。人们高呼、尖叫，并呼吁更多。整整一个星期，人群围攻了宾馆。他们在外面宽阔的广场上扎营，在露天吃喝玩乐39。

content_units.text: The tumultuous welcome affected even Nasir himself. Three weeks earlier, in a speech to the Egyptian National Assembly, he had struck a note of caution advising the Egyptians not to be swept by the emotions and excitement of the present into underestimating the inevitable problems that lay ahead.40 But now in Damascus, where the citys public squares had been transformed into some­thing akin to areas of public worship, Nasir could not but be moved by the adulation that surrounded him. He threw caution to the wind, and to the thunderous jubilation of the crowd, he pub­licly avowed his commitment to a broader unity of all the Arab people.41 It might have been a statement born out of the heady emotions of that moment, but the impact of his words went beyond the limited con.nes of Damascus, or Syria.42
content_units.azure_translation: 这种喧闹的欢迎甚至影响了纳西尔本人。三周前，在埃及国民议会的一次演讲中，他谨慎地建议埃及人不要被当前的情绪和兴奋所淹没，而低估了未来不可避免的问题。40 但现在在大马士革，城市的公共广场已经变成了类似于公共礼拜场所的东西， 纳西尔不禁被周围的奉承所感动。他把谨慎抛在脑后，在人群雷鸣般的欢呼声中，他公开宣称他致力于使所有阿拉伯人民更广泛地团结起来。41 这也许是出于当时令人陶醉的情绪而产生的声明，但他的话的影响超出了大马士革的有限范围， 或叙利亚42。

content_units.text: Fuad Matar, Bisaraha an Abd al-Nasir: Hiwar maa Muhamed Hasaneen Haykal (Frankly on Abd al-Nasir: a conversation with Muhamed Hasaneen Haykal) (Beirut: Dar al-Qadhaya, 1975), p. 137.

Al-Azm, Mudhakarat Khalid al-Azm (The memoirs of Khalid al-Azm), p. 165; see also the recollections of Akram al-Hourani in al-Quds al-Arabi, May 2930, 1999; Matar, Bisaraha an Abd al-Nasir (Frankly on Abd al-Nasir), p. 137; Hamroush, Qissat Thawrat 23 Yuliyu (The story of the 23 July revolution), p. 58. Hamroush relates that at some point during Nasirs visit to Aleppo, Nasirs car was carried on peoples shoulders.
Anwar Sadat, In Search of Identity: An Autobiography (New York: Harper and Row, 1977), p. 152.
The United Arab Republic, President Gamal Abd al-Nassers Speeches and Press Inter­views, 1958 (Cairo: Information Department, n.d.), p. 27.

Most troubling for the West was the response in Iraq, the citadel of the anti-Nasirist forces in the area. Abd al-Karim al-Uzri, a pil­lar of the monarchical political order and frequent cabinet member, describes in his memoirs the response at the popular level and among the ruling elite:
content_units.azure_translation: 最让西方感到不安的是伊拉克的反应，伊拉克是该地区反纳西尔主义势力的堡垒。阿卜杜勒·卡里姆·乌兹里 （Abd al-Karim al-Uzri） 是君主制政治秩序的支柱，经常担任内阁成员，他在回忆录中描述了民众层面和统治精英的反应：

content_units.text: [The UAR] generated among the educated and politically aware Iraqis an overwhelming sense of exuberance and ardor, and resusci­tated within them aspirations, the realization of which they had con­sidered to be no more than a dream.... [The formation of the UAR] also engendered extreme bitterness against the existing Iraqi politi­cal order for isolating Iraq from the Arabist tide, and distancing it from the unifying Arab nationalist movement. The unity between Egypt and Syria also caused a wave of fear and confusion among Iraqs rulers, the Western supporters of Iraq, some of the neigh­boring countries, and members of the Baghdad Pact, because of the immense dangers this unity would bring not only to Iraq, but also to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan and to Western interests in the area generally.43
content_units.azure_translation: [UAR]在受过教育和有政治意识的伊拉克人中产生了一种压倒性的活力和热情，并在他们内心重新燃起了愿望，他们认为实现这些愿望只不过是一个梦想......[UAR 的成立]还引起了对伊拉克现有政治秩序的极度怨恨，该秩序将伊拉克与阿拉伯主义浪潮隔离开来，并使其与统一的阿拉伯民族主义运动保持距离。埃及和叙利亚之间的统一也在伊拉克统治者、伊拉克的西方支持者、一些邻国和《巴格达条约》成员中引起了一波恐惧和混乱，因为这种统一不仅会给伊拉克带来巨大的危险，而且会给约旦哈希姆王国和西方在该地区的总体利益带来巨大的危险43。

content_units.text: The elation among Iraqs middle classstudents, professionals, businessmen, army of.cers, and so forthwas such that immense political risks were taken simply to register approval of the Egyp­tian-Syrian merger. Defying Nuri al-Said and his feared security apparatus, a number of prominent Iraqi politicians, journalists, and academics sent a congratulatory telegram to Nasir, in which the birth of the UAR was described as signifying a new era in the history of the Arab nation [whose] primary interest is to serve Arab nationalism.44 This public and pervasive endorsement of the UAR left the countrys rulers in a state of near despair. According to Britains Ambassador to Iraq, Crown Prince Abd al-Ilah believed that if the present trend of events, both inside Iraq and in the neighboring countries, continued without further check, the situa­tion would crumble irretrievably within a period of months and certainly before the end of the year. The impact of Nassers success and propaganda would prove too strong.45 Uzri too found the crown prince in a state of great fear and panic, telling Uzri that the UAR constituted a dangerous challenge to Iraq and a threat to its existence.46 Abd al-Ilah tried feverishly to induce the other members of the Baghdad Pact not to recognize the UAR on the grounds that the Egyptian-Syrian union was aimed not only against Iraqs interest, its security and its national goals, but also against its foreign policy, embodied in the countrys membership of the Baghdad Pact.47 But the crown prince was to be disappointed. Unpalatable as it might have been to the anti-nationalist forces, the UAR nevertheless had already been formed, was accorded enthusi­astic domestic support, and had received diplomatic recognition from countries such as the United States and Saudi Arabia. The Baghdad Pact countries therefore went ahead and recognized the UAR. As for Iraq, its recognition came only after the July 1958 revolution.
content_units.azure_translation: 伊拉克中产阶级学生、专业人士、商人、军队等的兴高采烈，以至于仅仅为了批准埃及-叙利亚的合并而冒着巨大的政治风险。一些著名的伊拉克政治家、记者和学者不顾努里·赛义德和他令人恐惧的安全机构，向纳西尔发出了一封贺电，其中将 UAR 的诞生描述为标志着阿拉伯民族主义历史上的一个新时代。44 这种对 UAR 的公开和普遍认可使该国统治者处于近乎绝望的状态。据英国驻伊拉克大使阿卜杜勒·伊拉王储称，如果伊拉克境内和邻国目前的事态发展趋势继续下去，没有进一步的制约，局势将在几个月内，当然在年底之前不可挽回地崩溃。纳赛尔的成功和宣传的影响将被证明是太强烈了。45 乌兹里也发现王储处于极度恐惧和恐慌的状态，他告诉乌兹里，UAR 对伊拉克构成了危险的挑战，对伊拉克的生存构成了威胁。46 阿卜杜勒·伊拉赫极力诱使《巴格达条约》其他成员国不承认《巴格达公约》，理由是埃及-叙利亚联盟不仅违背伊拉克的利益、安全和国家目标，而且违背了《巴格达条约》成员国所体现的外交政策。47 但王储却大失所望。尽管反民族主义势力可能令人不快，但 UAR 已经成立，得到了国内的热情支持，并得到了美国和沙特阿拉伯等国家的外交承认。因此，巴格达条约国家继续承认 UAR。至于伊拉克，直到 1958 年 7 月革命后才得到承认。

The great consternation felt by Iraqs rulers was more than echoed by Jordans King Husayn, saddled as he was by a large and radicalized Palestinian population. Immediately after the forma­tion of the UAR, King Husayn initiated a series of meetings with the Iraqi leaders which resulted in the creation of a federation to be named The Arab Union on February 14, 1958. In the .rst communique´ which announced the Hashemite union, the citizens of the new federated entity were reminded that it was the Hashem­ites (and by implication, not Abd al-Nasir) who were the real cus­todians of Arab nationalism, since it was Jordans Husayn and Iraqs Faysal who were the inheritors of the 1916 Great Arab Revolt and its eternal nationalist message. The two Hashemite kings constituted the .ame that would guide the Arab nation in its march toward its declared aspiration of comprehensive and uni­versal unity.48 The wording of the declaration is a testimony to the political sentiments and sensibilities of that era. In a political milieu in which Arab nationalism reigned supreme, it is under­standable that the two monarchies would resort to the only rele­vant political vocabulary of the time.
content_units.azure_translation: 伊拉克统治者所感受到的巨大震惊得到了约旦国王侯赛因的回应，他背负着大量激进的巴勒斯坦人口。UAR 成立后，侯赛因国王立即与伊拉克领导人举行了一系列会议，最终于 1958 年 2 月 14 日成立了一个名为阿拉伯联盟的联邦。在宣布哈希姆联盟的第一份公报中，新联邦实体的公民被提醒，哈希姆人（暗示，不是阿卜杜勒·纳西尔）才是阿拉伯民族主义的真正守护者，因为约旦·侯赛因和伊拉克·费萨尔是 1916 年阿拉伯大起义及其永恒的民族主义信息的继承者。两位哈希姆国王构成了引导阿拉伯民族朝着其宣布的全面和普遍统一的愿望迈进的 .ame。48 宣言的措辞证明了那个时代的政治情绪和情感。在阿拉伯民族主义占主导地位的政治环境中，两个君主制国家诉诸当时唯一相关的政治词汇是可以理解的。

But they were .ghting a losing battle. Their union was little more than an admission of their [own] weakness.49 It was evident from the discussions that preceded the announcement of the Arab Union that Amman and Baghdad were mounting an almost des­perate rearguard action to hold the line against Nasirs seemingly unstoppable Arab nationalist juggernaut. Thus, the Jordanian for­eign minister reminded the other participants that Egypts rulers . . . have expanded their goals, and have advocated a revolutionary philosophy which extended [beyond Egypt] to the Arab and Islamic worlds. It is therefore the duty of the governments of Iraq and Jor­dan to hold the line, for Jordan was their .rst target since it was the bridge that would take them to Iraq and Saudi Arabia.50 The problem was that the Union lacked public support. In contrast to the popular euphoria that greeted the founding of the UAR, the Arab Union was met with universal silence and lassitude.51 And indeed, the Hashemites themselves knew only too well that they had long lost the popularity contest; a realization which only inten­si.ed their rage at the UAR. This was more than evident in the exchange of letters between Nasir and Iraqs crown prince, Abd al-Ilah, after the formation of the Arab Union. Even though the Hashemites had not recognized the UAR, Nasir dispatched a warm congratulatory letter immediately after the announcement of the Arab Union. Nasirs letter spoke of his con.dence that the Arab Union would add strength to the Arab nation and would be a shield against that nations enemies. Nasir also called the formation of the Arab Union a proud day for Arab nationalism.52 Abd al-Ilah, writ­ing on behalf of the young King Faysal responded by .rst thanking Nasir, then reiterating the alleged long series of struggles that the Hashemites had waged on behalf of Arab nationalism which was bound to lead the Arabs to comprehensive unity. He ended the letter by asking the Almightys help in granting success and prosperity to all Arabs and Muslims.53 No mention of the UAR was made.
content_units.azure_translation: 但他们正在进行一场失败的战斗。他们的结合只不过是承认他们自己的弱点。49 从阿拉伯联盟宣布之前的讨论中可以明显看出，安曼和巴格达正在采取近乎绝望的后卫行动，以坚守对抗纳西尔这个看似势不可挡的阿拉伯民族主义巨头的防线。因此，约旦外交部长提醒其他与会者，埃及统治者......扩大了他们的目标，并倡导一种革命哲学，这种哲学[超越埃及]扩展到阿拉伯和伊斯兰世界。因此，伊拉克和约旦政府有责任坚守防线，因为约旦是他们的第一个目标，因为这是通往伊拉克和沙特阿拉伯的桥梁。50 问题在于联盟缺乏公众支持。与阿拉伯联合共和国成立时的民众欢欣鼓舞相反，阿拉伯联盟遭到了普遍的沉默和慵懒。51 事实上，哈希姆人自己也非常清楚，他们早已输掉了这场人气竞赛;这一认识只会加剧他们对 UAR 的愤怒。这在阿拉伯联盟成立后纳西尔与伊拉克王储阿卜杜勒·伊拉赫之间的信件往来中表现得非常明显。尽管哈希姆人没有承认阿拉伯联盟，但纳西尔在宣布成立阿拉伯联盟后立即发出了一封热情的贺信。纳西尔的信谈到了他认为阿拉伯联盟将增加阿拉伯民族的力量，并将成为抵御该国家敌人的盾牌。纳西尔还称阿拉伯联盟的成立是阿拉伯民族主义值得骄傲的一天。52 阿卜杜勒·伊拉赫代表年轻的费萨尔国王写信回应，首先感谢纳西尔，然后重申了哈希姆派为阿拉伯民族主义进行的所谓一系列长期斗争，这必将导致阿拉伯人走向全面统一。他在信的结尾请求全能者帮助所有阿拉伯人和穆斯林获得成功和繁荣。53 没有提到 UAR。

Abd al-Ilahs response is indicative of the psychological land­scape in which the Arab Union was born. The Hashemite initiative was defensive rather than creative, born not out of exuberance, but out of fear. The Unions discourse might have been dressed in Arab nationalist sentiment, but its actuality was different: it was a politi­cal venture, based on an institutional marriage, designed to mount a diplomatic and strategic counterpoint to Nasir in the region. It was meant to safeguard and reinforce not just the security and safety of the two kingdoms, but also of the other states threatened by the popular appeal of Arab nationalism, which was aided vigor­ously by Egypts propaganda, as well as on occasions by its intelli­gence services. One such threatened state was Lebanon with its highly polarized sectarian society.
content_units.azure_translation: 阿卜杜勒·伊拉赫的回应表明了阿拉伯联盟诞生的心理格局。哈希姆人的倡议是防御性的，而不是创造性的，不是出于兴奋，而是出于恐惧。联盟的话语可能披着阿拉伯民族主义情绪的外衣，但其现实却不同：这是一场基于制度联姻的政治冒险，旨在在该地区与纳西尔形成外交和战略对立。它不仅旨在维护和加强两个王国的安全，而且还要保护和加强受到阿拉伯民族主义民众号召力威胁的其他国家的安全，阿拉伯民族主义得到了埃及宣传的大力帮助，有时还得到了其情报部门的大力帮助。黎巴嫩就是这样一个受到威胁的国家，其宗派社会高度两极分化。

content_units.text: Lebanons political order was based on the Pact of 1943 be­tween Christian and Muslim leaders, which divided governmental responsibilities among the two religious communities. This tenu­ ous arrangement worked as long as the system did not come under any external strain. But the rise of Arab nationalism undermined the delicate balance, since the countrys politically dominant Chris­tian community saw in Arab nationalism and its ultimate goal of comprehensive Arab unity the dissolution of their separate identity and the loss of their political independence. It thus came as no surprise that the responses of the two communities to the an­nouncement of the UAR were radically different. In general, most Muslims rejoiced: many Muslim schools held celebratory rallies, and demonstrations in support of the new uni.ed state were held throughout Lebanon despite governmental bans. Delegation after delegation crossed over to Syria to congratulate its leaders on the historic decision. Most of the Christians, however, were simulta­neously and feverishly reiterating their faith in, and hopes for, the maintenance of Lebanons sovereignty.
content_units.azure_translation: 黎巴嫩的政治秩序基于 1943 年基督教和穆斯林领导人之间的条约，该条约将政府责任分配给两个宗教团体。只要系统不受任何外部压力，这种脆弱的安排就会奏效。但阿拉伯民族主义的兴起破坏了这种微妙的平衡，因为在政治上占主导地位的基督教社区在阿拉伯民族主义及其全面阿拉伯统一的最终目标中看到了他们各自身份的瓦解和政治独立性的丧失。因此，两个社区对 UAR 的宣布的反应截然不同也就不足为奇了。总的来说，大多数穆斯林都感到高兴：许多穆斯林学校举行了庆祝集会，尽管政府禁止，但黎巴嫩各地仍举行了支持新一元国家的示威活动。一个又一个代表团前往叙利亚，祝贺叙利亚领导人做出这一历史性决定。然而，大多数基督徒同时狂热地重申他们对维护黎巴嫩主权的信仰和希望。

This increasing polarization erupted into a full-.edged civil war in May 1958, which President Camille Chamoun and his foreign minister, Charles Malik, both Christians, blamed entirely on the UAR and its leaders. It seems that Malik, troubled by the vexatious spectacle of hordes of Lebanese arriving in Damascus and shouting for Arab unity under Nasirs leadership,54 had taken it upon himself to be the .rst line of defense against the irredentist Nasirist tide. It was Malik who convinced Chamoun to go to the United Nations Security Council, citing UAR interference in Lebanons internal af­fairs. In his address to the Security Council, Malik alleged that the interference was conducted through a large supply of arms to anti-government forces, training of subversive elements in Syria, partici­pation of UAR nationals in the civil war, and employment of hostile press and radio campaigns against Lebanons government.55 As it turned out, United Nations observers who were sent to Lebanon vitiated Maliks claims of arms supply or personnel in.ltration from the UAR. But that was not necessarily Maliks goal. What he and Chamoun were really after could be discerned from the complaints conclusion, which characterized UAR activity as repre­senting a danger to international peace and security.56 These were the very words used in the Eisenhower Doctrine, and as Malik was careful to link UAR action to international Communism,57 his appeal was meant to speci.cally target the United States and its allies, particularly members of the Baghdad Pact.
content_units.azure_translation: 这种日益严重的两极分化在 1958 年 5 月爆发了一场全面的内战，总统卡米尔·查蒙 （Camille Chamoun） 和他的外交部长查尔斯·马利克 （Charles Malik） 都是基督徒，他们完全将这场内战归咎于 UAR 及其领导人。马利克似乎对成群结队的黎巴嫩人抵达大马士革并高呼在纳西尔领导下的阿拉伯团结54的无理取闹的景象感到困扰，54 他自己承担了抵御不可逆转的纳西尔主义浪潮的第一道防线的责任。正是马利克说服查蒙前往联合国安理会，理由是 UAR 干涉黎巴嫩内政。马利克在向安全理事会发表讲话时声称，干涉是通过向反政府部队提供大量武器、在叙利亚训练颠覆分子、让阿拉伯联合共和国国民参与内战以及利用敌对新闻和广播运动来反对黎巴嫩政府进行的。55 事实证明，派往黎巴嫩的联合国观察员推翻了马利克关于阿拉伯联合共和国提供武器或人员的说法。但这不一定是马利克的目标。从投诉结论中可以看出他和查蒙真正想要什么，该结论将 UAR 的活动描述为对国际和平与安全构成威胁。56 这正是艾森豪威尔主义中使用的词语，由于马利克小心翼翼地将 UAR 的行动与国际共产主义联系起来，57 他的呼吁旨在专门针对美国及其盟国，特别是巴格达条约的成员。

Not surprisingly, the country that took up the challenge was Iraq. As the only Arab member of the Baghdad Pact, Iraq would naturally take a proactive stance on the matter. And in any case, the possibility of Lebanons disintegration, or worse its absorption by the UAR, had to be a matter of immense concern for the Iraqi leadership. Indeed, Iraqs foreign minister, Fadhil al-Jamali, was dispatched to the United Nations and worked closely with Charles Malik, delivering a speech that asserted Iraqs wholehearted sup­port for Lebanon against the scourge of Nasserism.58 Nuri al­Said followed this diplomatic move by calling an emergency high-level meeting of the Baghdad Pact to be held in Istanbul on July
content_units.azure_translation: 毫不奇怪，接受挑战的国家是伊拉克。作为《巴格达条约》唯一的阿拉伯成员国，伊拉克自然会在这个问题上采取积极主动的立场。无论如何，黎巴嫩解体的可能性，或者更糟糕的是，黎巴嫩被阿拉伯联合军吸收的可能性，必须是伊拉克领导层极度关切的问题。事实上，伊拉克外交部长法迪尔·贾马利被派往联合国，与查尔斯·马利克密切合作，发表讲话，宣称伊拉克全心全意地支持黎巴嫩，反对纳赛尔主义的祸害。58 努里·赛义德 （Nuri alSaid） 紧随这一外交举措，呼吁 7 月在伊斯坦布尔召开《巴格达公约》紧急高级别会议

content_units.text: 14. Simultaneously, he ordered army units to move into northern Jordan near the border of Syria and Lebanon.
content_units.azure_translation: 14. 同时，他命令军队进入靠近叙利亚和黎巴嫩边境的约旦北部。

content_units.text: But when the Baghdad Pact meeting convened, Iraqs seat was vacant, and the army units never arrived in Jordan. The units, sta­tioned about 90 miles northeast of Baghdad, stopped their journey to Amman short, occupying instead the Iraqi capital, and with the collaboration of other army units toppled the monarchical political order, killing Nuri al-Said, King Faysal II, Crown Prince Abd al-Ilah, and the other members of the royal family, and proclaimed the birth of the Iraqi Republic. In one dramatic, albeit gruesomely bloody, day, Nasir witnessed the demise of his greatest antagonist and most capable foe. Revolutionary Arab nationalism had achieved yet another remarkable triumph. And surely more were on the way, or so everyone believed.
content_units.azure_translation: 但当巴格达条约会议召开时，伊拉克的席位空缺，军队部队从未抵达约旦。这些部队驻扎在巴格达东北约 90 英里处，短暂停止了前往安曼的旅程，转而占领了伊拉克首都，并在其他军队部队的配合下推翻了君主制政治秩序，杀死了努里·赛义德、国王费萨尔二世、王储阿卜杜勒·伊拉赫和其他王室成员，并宣布伊拉克共和国的诞生。在一个戏剧性的、尽管血腥的一天里，纳西尔目睹了他最大的对手和最有能力的敌人的死亡。革命的阿拉伯民族主义又取得了一次非凡的胜利。当然，还有更多的事情正在路上，至少每个人都这么相信。

content_units.text: See Fawzi Abu Diab, Lubnan wa al-Ummam al-Muttahida (Lebanon and the United Nations) (Beirut: Dar al-Nahdha al-Arabiya, 1971), p. 139. 57 Dimashqiya, Mahattat . Hayati al-Diblomasiya (Stations in my diplomatic life), p. 121122. 58 Muhamed Fadhil al-Jamali, Safahat min Tarikhina al-Muasir (Pages from our contem­porary history) (Cairo: Dar Suad al-Sabah, 1993), p. 197.

The odds-on favorite to be the next to fall prey to the Arab na­tionalist avalanche was Hashemite Jordan. The Arab Union, the very arrangement fashioned by King Husayn for his own protec­tion, lay in ruins, smothered in the blood of those who, like him, had dared to confront Nasir and Arab nationalism. In sheer desper­ation, he tried to decouple the man from the movement: We want Nasir to know that Arab nationalism was born before he was.59 True. But in the political milieu of the time, these were hollow words, the words of a man seemingly enveloped by a sense of hope­lessness, of a relic of the reactionary past trying to cast asper­sions on the man of the hour, the acknowledged hero of triumphant Arab nationalism. To most Arabs and indeed non-Arabs, it was a foregone conclusion that Husayn was doomed. In his biography of the king, the British journalist, Peter Snow, who reported from Amman in the wake of the Iraqi revolution, describes vividly the mood and expectations of those days:
content_units.azure_translation: 下一个成为阿拉伯民族主义雪崩牺牲品的热门人选是哈希姆约旦。阿拉伯联盟，即侯赛因国王为保护自己而制定的安排，已经成为废墟，被那些像他一样敢于对抗纳西尔和阿拉伯民族主义的人的鲜血所窒息。在绝望中，他试图将这个人与运动脱钩：我们想让纳西尔知道，阿拉伯民族主义在他之前就已经诞生了。59 没错。但在当时的政治环境中，这些都是空洞的话，一个似乎被绝望感笼罩的人的话，是反动过去的遗物，试图诋毁这位时代风云人物，这位被公认为胜利的阿拉伯民族主义英雄。对于大多数阿拉伯人，甚至非阿拉伯人来说，侯赛因注定要失败已成定局。伊拉克革命后从安曼报道的英国记者彼得·斯诺（Peter Snow）在他的国王传记中生动地描述了当时的情绪和期望：

content_units.text: [P]eople expected to wake up each morning to hear that [the King] had been assassinated. Talk of conspiracy was everywhere. There were a number of bomb explosions, a large number of arrests and a ruthless clampdown by Husseins security forces. Censorship was imposed on the press. Those were some of the most tense days the King ever had to endure. Journalists, many of whom had to leave the country to .le their reports, told of open public support for Presi­dent Nasir and the widely held assumption that Jordan would fol­low Iraq into the revolutionary camp.60
content_units.azure_translation: [P]人们预计每天早上醒来都会听到[国王]被暗杀的消息。阴谋的讨论无处不在。发生了多起炸弹爆炸、大量逮捕和侯赛因安全部队的无情镇压。对新闻界实施了审查制度。那是国王不得不忍受的最紧张的日子。记者们（其中许多人不得不离开该国去撰写他们的报道）讲述了公众对纳西尔总统的公开支持，以及人们普遍认为约旦将跟随伊拉克加入革命阵营的假设60。

content_units.text: Even the U. S. government seemed to share in the general sense of doom surrounding the kings prospects. A directive by the United
content_units.azure_translation: 就连美国政府似乎也认同围绕国王前景的普遍厄运感。美国的指令

content_units.text: Quoted in Michael N. Barnett, Dialogues in Arab Politics: Negotiations in Regional Order (New York: Columbia University Press, 1998), p. 134.
Peter Snow, Hussein: A Biography (New York: Robert B. Luce, Inc., 1972), pp. 128 129.

States National Security Council stated that the inde.nite contin­uance of Jordans present political status has been rendered unreal­istic by recent developments. The directive went on to recommend in the face of the irresistible forces of nationalism, anti-monar­chism, and anti-colonialism, the most that could be hoped for was an orderly devolution leading to Husseins digni.ed withdrawal and an agreed absorption of Jordan by its Arab neighbors.61
content_units.azure_translation: 各国国家安全委员会表示，由于最近的事态发展，约旦目前的政治地位的永久延续已经变得不现实。该指令继续建议，面对民族主义、反君主制和反殖民主义的不可抗拒的力量，最希望的是有序的权力下放，导致侯赛因的撤军和阿拉伯邻国同意吞并约旦。61

content_units.text: Realizing perhaps that his hours were numbered if he did not act swiftly, Husayn requested British military aid. Prime Minister Harold Macmillan decided on an immediate airlift of .fteen hun­dred troops from Cyprus to Amman. But they had to .y over the airspace of the normally recalcitrant Israelis. However, as it turned out, Israeli approval was never in doubt, since in the words of For­eign Minister Golda Meir, the Israelis prayed three times a day for King Husseins safety and success.62 On July 17, British para­troopers landed in Amman, their numbers swelling eventually to four thousand. They stayed in Jordan until the king deemed the dangers to have dissipated. While undoubtedly the presence of the troops bolstered immeasurably the tottering monarchy, they never­theless represented for the king a humiliating af.rmation of Egypts claims that imperialism was in the service of Arab reactionary leaders in their efforts to save themselves from the wrath of Arab nationalism and its committed disciples all over the Arab world. Egypt had made the same derisive accusation two days earlier when American troops landed in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, to save that other hapless reactionary leader, Camille Chamoun.
content_units.azure_translation: 侯赛因意识到，如果他不迅速采取行动，他的时间也许已经屈指可数了，于是请求英国提供军事援助。哈罗德·麦克米伦总理决定立即从塞浦路斯空运 100 名士兵到安曼。但他们不得不飞越通常顽固的以色列人的领空。然而，事实证明，以色列的批准是毫无疑问的，因为用外交部长戈尔达·梅尔的话来说，以色列人每天为侯赛因国王的安全和成功祈祷三次。62 7 月 17 日，英国伞兵在安曼登陆，人数最终增加到 4000 人。他们留在约旦河，直到国王认为危险已经消散。虽然军队的存在无疑极大地支持了摇摇欲坠的君主制，但他们仍然对国王表示了一种羞辱性的反击，埃及声称帝国主义是为阿拉伯反动领导人服务的，他们努力将自己从阿拉伯民族主义及其忠实的门徒的愤怒中拯救出来。两天前，当美军在黎巴嫩首都贝鲁特登陆以拯救另一位倒霉的反动领导人卡米尔·查蒙时，埃及也提出了同样的嘲讽性指控。

content_units.text: In Iraq, the new revolutionary government under the leadership of General Abd al-Karim Qasim and Colonel Abd al-Salam Aref promptly reversed its predecessors policies, declaring itself to be part of the Arab nationalist struggle. Its .rst foreign policy act was the recognition of the UAR. A mere .ve days after the coup, on July 19, Colonel Aref led a high-level Iraqi delegation to Damascus where he met with Nasir. In a number of public speeches to huge and ecstatic crowds both characterized the Iraqi revolution as a crowning achievement of Arab nationalism. And in this the two leaders were simply responding to peoples sentiments, for this was indeed the main theme of the slogans thundered by the crowds that .lled the streets of Damascus once news of the Iraqi revolution reached Syrias capital.63 And the Syrian demonstrators themselves were only echoing their brethren in Iraq who .lled the streets, and who, in their frenzied chants, promised themselves to Nasir as his .ock, his loyal cavalry.64 So it was hardly a surprise when, in the meetings between Nasir and the Iraqi delegation, Aref expressed his hope that Iraq would soon join the UAR.65 And the crowds that .lled the streets sang and danced and expected nothing less.
content_units.azure_translation: 在伊拉克，由阿卜杜勒·卡里姆·卡西姆将军和阿卜杜勒·萨拉姆·阿雷夫上校领导的新革命政府迅速扭转了前任的政策，宣称自己是阿拉伯民族主义斗争的一部分。它的第一个外交政策法案是承认 UAR。政变发生仅几天后，即 7 月 19 日，阿雷夫上校率领伊拉克高级代表团前往大马士革，在那里他会见了纳西尔。在对大量欣喜若狂的群众发表的多次公开演讲中，两人都将伊拉克革命描述为阿拉伯民族主义的最高成就。在这一点上，两位领导人只是在回应人民的情绪，因为这确实是伊拉克革命的消息传到叙利亚首都后，在大马士革街头的人群高喊口号的主题。63 而叙利亚示威者自己也只是在呼应他们在伊拉克的兄弟们，他们走上街头， 他们在疯狂的口号中向纳西尔承诺自己是他的 .ock，他忠诚的骑兵。64 因此，当纳西尔和伊拉克代表团的会面中，阿雷夫表示希望伊拉克尽快加入 UAR 时，也就不足为奇了。65 街上的群众又唱又舞，期待着。

content_units.text: Dann, King Hussein and the Challenge of Arab Radicalism,p.93.
Quoted in Avi Shlaim, Israel, the Great Powers, and the Middle East Crisis of 1958, The Journal of Imperial and Commonwealth History, vol. 27, no. 2 (May 1999): 185.

If an analyst could legitimately step back and isolate one speci.c period, be it a week, a month, a year, from the ongoing procession of historical development, and point to this period in time as the very apex, the .owering climax, of whatever historical story he or she is telling, then the period after the Iraqi revolution, short-lived as it turned out to be, represented the very peak of the relentless upward rise of Arab nationalism. In that brief historical moment, the jubilant and energized masses genuinely and fervently believed that they had witnessed the .nal and ignominious defeat of those they considered to be the enemies of Arab nationalism. Moved by this victorious spirit, they could now hope, for the .rst time in almost .ve hundred years, to turn their glorious past into a glitter­ing and heroic future. The process would begin by the entry of Iraq into the UAR, which was accepted as a foregone conclusion, and this would constitute the rock upon which Nasir would build the
content_units.azure_translation: 如果一个分析家可以合法地退后一步，将一个特定的时期，无论是一周、一个月还是一年，从正在进行的历史发展进程中分离出来，并指出这段时间是他或她所讲述的任何历史故事的顶点，即高潮，那么伊拉克革命之后的时期， 事实证明，这是短暂的，但代表了阿拉伯民族主义无情上升的顶峰。在那个短暂的历史时刻，欢欣鼓舞、充满活力的群众真诚而热切地相信，他们目睹了那些他们认为是阿拉伯民族主义敌人的人的惨败和可耻的失败。被这种胜利精神所感动，他们现在可以希望，近一百年来第一次，将他们辉煌的过去变成辉煌而英勇的未来。这一进程将从伊拉克加入 UAR 开始，这被认为是已成定局的，这将构成纳西尔建立

Arab nation-state. After all, Egypt, Syria, and Iraq were the geo­graphic and cultural heart of the Arab world, and their unity would trigger a tidal wave that would sweep all skeptics and naysayers into historical oblivion.
content_units.azure_translation: 阿拉伯民族国家。毕竟，埃及、叙利亚和伊拉克是阿拉伯世界的地理和文化中心，它们的团结将引发一股浪潮，将所有怀疑论者和反对者卷入历史遗忘之中。

content_units.text: The nationalist generation unquestioningly believed that they had formed a nation; the state now awaited them.
content_units.azure_translation: 民族主义一代毫无疑问地相信他们已经形成了一个国家;国家现在在等着他们。

content_units.text: The announcement broadcast on Radio Baghdad on September 11, 1958 was curt, uncharacteristically devoid of the kind of hyperbole to which Iraqi listeners had become accustomed since the outset of the revolution. It said simply: In view of the dictates of public interest and upon the recommendation of the Minister of Defense, we decree the following: to relieve Staff Colonel Abd al Salam Aref from his post as Deputy Commander in Chief of the armed forces.1 Three weeks or so later, in an even shorter statement, General Abd al-Karim Qasim relieved Aref of all his cabinet posts, and adding insult to injury, appointed him ambassa­dor to Bonn.2
content_units.azure_translation: 1958 年 9 月 11 日在巴格达广播电台播出的公告很生硬，一反常态地没有伊拉克听众自革命开始以来就习惯的那种夸张。它简单地说：鉴于公共利益的要求，根据国防部长的建议，我们下令：解除阿卜杜勒·萨拉姆·阿雷夫上校的武装部队副总司令职务。1 大约三周后，阿卜杜勒·卡里姆·卡西姆将军在一份更简短的声明中解除了阿雷夫的所有内阁职务，雪上加霜的是，任命他为驻波恩大使。

content_units.text: The heart of every Arab nationalist must have skipped a beat or two at the news of Arefs demotion. Of the two leaders of the Iraqi revolution, he was seen as the one who was committed wholly, and without any reservations, not just to Arab nationalist ideals and principles, but also to unity with the United Arab Republic (UAR).
content_units.azure_translation: 每个阿拉伯民族主义者的心一定在阿雷夫斯降职的消息上跳了一两拍。在伊拉克革命的两位领导人中，他被视为完全、毫无保留地致力于阿拉伯民族主义理想和原则，而且致力于与阿拉伯联合共和国（UAR）的统一。

content_units.text: Benjamin Shwadran, The Power Struggle in Iraq (New York: Council for Middle East­ern Affairs Press, 1960), p. 35.
Ibid.

It was Aref who, without consulting Qasim, had demanded imme­diate unity with the UAR in his .rst talks with Gamal Abd al-Nasir in Damascus a few days after the military takeover in Iraq. He is reported to have told Nasir not to bother with Qasim, por­traying his senior partner as Iraqs Neguib3 (the early .gurehead of Egypts revolution who was later ousted by Nasir). He even went so far as to tell Nasir that if Qasim were to object to unity with the UAR, then he, Aref, would kill him with one bullet. Taken aback, Nasir interrupted Aref, telling him: No, brother Abd al-Salam. Let us not have this kind of talk. He (Qasim) is your senior col­league, and things have to be done through dialogue and persua­sion.4 Back in Iraq, Aref blazed his way through the length and breadth of the land, making numerous speeches, in which he ex­tolled the virtue of Arab unity and the leadership of Nasir. The UAR president was undoubtedly his hero, which moved one foe to remark that in his speeches, Aref ignored the leader of the revolu­tion (Qasim) and praised Jamal Abd al-Nasir. Was Abd al-Nasir the leader of the revolution?5 Indeed, Qasim, who by then was being called by his own supporters, al-Zaim al-Awhad (the sole leader) was hardly enamored with his junior partner. He made a point of devaluing Arefs role in Iraqs revolution to foreign visi­tors.6 More concretely, Qasim began to quietly clip Arefs wings by undercutting his power base in the army, while Aref gallivanted around the country making speeches.7 By September, Qasim felt strong enough to dispatch Aref to Bonn. Aref, however, resisted his unceremonious exit, and for his pains was arrested on Novem­ber 4 on the charge of plotting against the security of the home­land.8 This date marks the .rst erosion in the hitherto seemingly all-conquering Arab nationalist movement.
content_units.azure_translation: 正是阿雷夫在没有咨询卡西姆的情况下，在伊拉克军事接管几天后，在大马士革与贾迈勒·阿卜杜勒·纳西尔的第一次会谈中要求立即与阿拉伯联合起来。据报道，他告诉纳西尔不要理会卡西姆，将他的高级搭档描绘成伊拉克人内吉布3（埃及革命的早期领头人，后来被纳西尔赶下台）。他甚至告诉纳西尔，如果卡西姆反对与 UAR 团结，那么他，阿雷夫，会用一颗子弹杀死他。纳西尔大吃一惊，打断了阿雷夫的话，告诉他：不，阿卜杜勒·萨拉姆兄弟。我们不要进行这种谈话。他（卡西姆）是你的高级同事，事情必须通过对话和说服来完成。4 回到伊拉克后，阿雷夫在这片土地上大放异彩，发表了许多演讲，在演讲中他赞扬了阿拉伯团结的美德和纳西尔的领导能力。UAR 主席无疑是他的英雄，这感动了一位敌人，说阿雷夫在演讲中无视革命领袖（卡西姆），并赞扬了贾迈勒·阿卜杜勒·纳西尔。阿卜杜勒·纳西尔是革命的领袖吗？5 事实上，卡西姆当时被自己的支持者称为扎伊姆·阿哈德（al-Zaim al-Awhad）（唯一的领导人）对他的初级伙伴几乎不感兴趣。6 更具体地说，卡西姆开始悄悄地削弱阿雷夫在军队中的权力基础，从而削弱阿雷夫的羽翼，而阿雷夫则在全国各地驰骋发表演讲。7 到 9 月，卡西姆觉得自己足够强大，可以派遣阿雷夫前往波恩。然而，阿雷夫拒绝了他毫不客气的退出，并因痛苦而于 11 月 4 日被捕，罪名是密谋危害祖国的安全。8 这一天标志着迄今为止看似无所不能的阿拉伯民族主义运动的第一次侵蚀。

The speaker was Colonel Majid Amin, the leftist prosecutor general of Mahkamat al­Shaab (the Peoples Court), which was set up immediately after the revolution to try mem­bers of the ancien regime, but in due course became a vehicle for settling scores as the revolution turned in on itself. This statement was made in Arefs trial for allegedly at­tempting to assassinate Qasim. See Shwadran, The Power Struggle in Iraq,p.37.
See, for example, Salah Nasr, Abd al-Nasir wa Tajribat al-Wuhda (Abd al-Nasir and the unity experiment) (Beirut: al-Watan al-Arabi, 1976), pp. 171172, 175.
Khadduri, Republican Iraq, pp. 9293.

What was especially worrying for the Arab nationalists was that the arrest of Aref seemed to result not just from the personal ri­valry between the two leaders of the Iraqi revolution, but from a wider political divide among and within the progressive forces that together had toppled the ancien regime. Behind Aref were the nationalists, those who demanded immediate unity: Bathists, Nasirists, and the like. Qasim, however, had created a coalition consisting of Communists, Kurds, unaf.liated leftists, and Iraqi nationalists, such as those who belonged to the National Demo­cratic Party. As the struggle intensi.ed, the dormant sectarian sen­sitivities surfaced again, depicting the efforts at Arab unity as es­sentially a Sunni project, designed to ensure the ultimate subjugation of the non-Sunni communal groups. The group that coalesced around Qasim adopted the slogan Iraq.rst as a coun­terbalance to the Arab nationalist demand of unity now. The Iraq.rst group was not necessarily averse to some form of union, but theirs was a much looser conception than that held by the nationalists, at most a federal arrangement in which Iraq would retain considerable autonomy.
content_units.azure_translation: 阿拉伯民族主义者尤其担心的是，阿雷夫的被捕似乎不仅是由于伊拉克革命的两位领导人之间的个人竞争，而且是由于共同推翻旧政权的进步力量之间和内部更广泛的政治分歧。阿雷夫的背后是民族主义者，那些要求立即团结的人：巴蒂斯特人、纳西尔主义者等等。然而，卡西姆创建了一个由共产党人、库尔德人、无宗教信仰的左翼分子和伊拉克民族主义者（例如属于国家民主党的人）组成的联盟。随着斗争的加剧，沉睡的宗派敏感性再次浮出水面，将阿拉伯团结的努力描述为本质上是一个逊尼派项目，旨在确保最终征服非逊尼派社区团体。围绕卡西姆团结起来的团体采用了“伊拉克第一”的口号，以制衡阿拉伯民族主义现在的团结要求。伊拉克第一集团不一定反对某种形式的联合，但他们的概念比民族主义者所持有的要宽松得多，最多是一种联邦安排，伊拉克将保留相当大的自治权。

content_units.text: The con.ict came to a head on March 9, 1959 when an at­tempted coup against Qasim by Arab nationalist of.cers failed. The rebellion, centered in the northern city of Mosul, received sub­stantial help from the UAR. The point man was Colonel Abd al-Hamid Saraj, head of intelligence in the UARs northern region (Syria). Saraj was apprised of the conspiracy from its very incep­tion, and his men held a number of meetings with the Iraqi conspir­ators, who received not only arms and money, but prior to the announcement of the rebellion, also a radio transmitter to balance
content_units.azure_translation: 1959 年 3 月 9 日，阿拉伯民族主义者针对卡西姆的政变未遂失败，这场争论达到了顶峰。这场以北部城市摩苏尔为中心的叛乱得到了 UAR 的大力帮助。关键人物是阿卜杜勒·哈米德·萨拉吉上校，他是阿卜杜勒·哈米德·萨拉吉上校，他是阿卜杜勒·哈米德·萨拉吉上校，他是阿卜杜勒·哈米德·萨拉吉上校，他是阿卜杜勒·哈米德·萨拉吉上校，他是阿卜杜勒·哈米德·萨拉吉上校，他是阿卜萨拉吉从阴谋一开始就被告知，他的手下与伊拉克阴谋者举行了多次会议，他们不仅收到了武器和金钱，而且在宣布叛乱之前还收到了无线电发射器以平衡

content_units.text: British Broadcasting Corporation, Summary ofWorld Broadcasts, Part IV: The Arab World, Israel, Greece, Turkey, Iran (hereafter cited as SWB), November 6, 1958, p. 6.

Radio Baghdad which was controlled by Qasim loyalists. In­deed, Nasir, who was on a visit to Damascus, prolonged his stay in anticipation of the coups success and Qasims removal.9 The break now was total, the mood never more bitter, the rhetoric ma­levolently shrill and personal.
content_units.azure_translation: 巴格达广播电台，由卡西姆的忠诚者控制。事实上，正在访问大马士革的纳西尔延长了逗留时间，以期政变成功和卡西姆斯被赶走。9 现在彻底的休息，情绪从未像现在这样痛苦，言辞恶毒而尖锐和个人化。

content_units.text: The invective began in Iraqs Mahkamat al-Shaab (Peoples Court), which over the previous months had been holding daily public and televised trials of prominent members of the monar­chys political order. The prosecutor accused the UAR of direct involvement in, and responsibility for, the failed coup attempt, and called Nasir a pharaoh.10 The president of the court, Colonel Fad­hil al-Mahdawi, identi.ed the pharaoh in question as none other than Ramsis, adding an impromptu rhyme: Nasir ya Ramsis, ya Khadim al-Ingilis (Nasir, O Ramsis, O Servant of the En-glish).11 Meaningless as this rhyme might have been, it was met with ecstatic approval in the theater that was Mahkamat al­Shaab, which as a rule was .lled with die-hard Qasim supporters. Nasir countered with his own battery of personal insults, labeling Qasim a Communist, an anti-Arab, and most famous of all Qasim al-Iraq (divider of Iraq).12 He also belittled Qasims role in the Iraqi revolution, and insinuated that it was Abd al-Salam Aref who was the real leader of the revolution.13 The UARs pro­paganda machine continued relentlessly this character assassina­tion, linking Qasim with every anti-Arab cause and endeavor, and pouncing on his increasing reliance on the leftists and Communists in his struggle with Iraqs pro-Nasir nationalists. Naturally, the Voice of the Arabs made sure to work the universally detested Israel into the mix:
content_units.azure_translation: 谩骂始于伊拉克人民法院，在过去的几个月里，该法院每天都对君主制政治秩序的知名成员进行公开和电视审判。检察官指责 UAR 直接参与了失败的政变企图并对其负责，并称纳西尔为法老。10 法院院长法迪尔·马赫达维上校指认涉案法老不是别人，正是拉姆西斯，并添加了即兴押韵：Nasir ya Ramsis， ya Khadim al-Ingilis（纳西尔，拉姆西斯，英格利什的仆人啊）。11 尽管这首押韵毫无意义， 它在 Mahkamat alShaab 剧院得到了欣喜若狂的认可，该剧院通常受到卡西姆铁杆支持者的欢迎。纳西尔用他自己的一系列人身侮辱进行反击，将卡西姆贴上共产主义者、反阿拉伯人、最著名的伊拉克卡西姆（伊拉克分裂者）的标签。12 他还贬低了卡西姆在伊拉克革命中的作用，并暗示阿卜杜勒·萨拉姆·阿雷夫才是革命的真正领袖。13 UAR 的宣传机器无情地继续这种人物暗杀， 将卡西姆与每一项反阿拉伯事业和努力联系起来，并在与伊拉克亲纳西尔民族主义者的斗争中对左翼和共产党人日益依赖。自然地，阿拉伯人之声确保将普遍厌恶的以色列纳入其中：
